abstract.p: Julie Yates Walton reviews following children's books: Around My Room by William Jay Smith; and Is It Far to Zanzibar?: Poems About Tanzania by Nikki Grimes; drawing (M)

block.p: Reading the latest works of these two very different poets is like visiting with two beloved but very different relatives. There's the wise old aunt (Nikki Grimes), who pulls you on her lap and spins colorful, instructional yarns of her travels. You either love them and beg for more, or you wiggle out of her lap and run over to your uncle (William Jay Smith), who throws you up in the air and makes you giggle at nonsense.
Which one do you want at the family reunion? Both, definitely. Each poet speaks to a different kind of child, or perhaps a child in a particular mood.

Smith's collection is for children who are in the mood for silliness. While there is plenty of strong new material, many of the 29 poems previously appeared in his ''Laughing Time: Nonsense Poems'' (1955). ''Around My Room'' successfully reaches out to a younger audience. Erik Blegvad's illustrations nicely ground the verbal shenanigans with his crisp, consistently lovely, whimsical watercolors. He respects the literal shapes of Smith's poems, wrapping his pictures around the text while leaving plenty of white space. Blegvad's art never overpowers the poems, but some of them cry out for a bit more levity, as in, say, ''The Fat-Cat Circus'':

This scene should be a feast of irony, and yet it is played so straight that it manages to look perfectly natural to see cats on horses, and a cat wielding a top hat and whip. The visual humor -- for a younger audience especially -- is occasionally too subtle.

For the most part, though, Blegvad and Smith are a delightful pairing. Smith's talent endures, as seen in the seamless blend of old and new offerings. Reading the old poem ''The Toaster,'' we again revel in the fantasy of having one's own personal dragon:
A silver-scaled Dragon with jaws flaming red
Sits at my elbow and toasts my bread.
I hand him fat slices, and then, one by one,
He hands them back when he sees they are done.
A newer selection, ''The Kid From Nebraska,'' is a series of limericks in which Smith's intelligent silliness shines through:
In the swamp in the fog

Nikki Grimes's work typically burrows into deeper life issues. In the recent ''Jazmin's Notebook'' (a Coretta Scott King honor book), she explores the journal of a 14-year-old girl in Harlem: a dead father, a distant mother, an attempted rape are all part of her world. Grimes's long career in prose and poetry exhibits a breathtaking range in tone and style, but generally focuses on urban African-American environments. In ''Is It Far to Zanzibar?'' she ventures off the familiar urban stage into the exotic world of Tanzania. The first poem, ''Down the Road a Bit,'' wryly dramatizes how she, as poet, is luring us, the readers, to open our eyes to a new culture:
Walk down the road a bit, cousin.
Walk down the road a bit.
The place you're seeking, I will help you to find.

This invitation to meet our Tanzanian cousins is underscored by a man in a Western-style suit, carrying a suitcase, walking past pawpaw groves and shirtless old men carving masks and giraffes. Like this wide-eyed traveler, we begin to grasp that we aren't in Kansas (or Harlem) anymore.

The tone is as light and refreshing as the luscious fruit Grimes describes in ''Many Mangoes'': ''Ripe and sweet, juicy meat. / A few shillings only for a tasty treat.'' There are no deep issues here, just the pleasure and enlightenment of stepping into another life for a while. Grimes does not use Tanzania as a mere backdrop for storytelling; the land's geography and culture give breath to every line. Swahili words are sprinkled throughout; a glossary and map are included.

The poems deal with such exotic experiences as picking coffee, being chased up a tree by a lion, and sharing a bus with ''squawking chickens near my seat, / billy goats sniff at my feet.'' But Grimes also wisely bridges the cultural gap with ''Haraka, Haraka'' (''Hurry, Hurry''), which shows how, in some ways, Tanzanian children are not so very different from their Western cousins:
Aina baraka. There's no blessing in it.
The elders tell me this each day,
I eat my porridge while it's too hot.
I scream and burn my tongue a lot!
I rush to fill the water pail,
Then spill the water without fail!

Betsy Lewin's illustrations follow Grimes's lighthearted lead with watercolors in a cartoonish, exuberant fashion. Like Grimes, Lewin has traveled to East Africa, and blends her firsthand knowledge of that land with vivid color and playful renderings.
''Around My Room'' may have an edge in the rollicking good fun department, but ''Is It Far to Zanzibar?'' offers a lively, albeit quieter, peek at the great big world that lies beyond one's bedroom.

THE CENTURY THAT WAS: Reflections on the Last One Hundred Years. Edited by James Cross Giblin. Atheneum. $19.95. (Ages 10 and up) Essays by 11 diverse and distinguished children's authors, ranging from the biographers Russell Freedman and Milton Meltzer to the novelists Walter Dean Myers and Lois Lowry. They have written essays on aspects of the 20th century that give an eccentric but intriguing glimpse of times just past, including attitudes toward the environment, civil rights, amateur and professional sports, the impact of World War I. It's a provocative collection by writers young readers know and respect. THE COOKIE COMPANY. By Ross Venokur. Delacorte. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12) On Alex Grindlay's 13th birthday, a mysterious deliveryman brings a Chinese dinner to the morose and motherless boy. The fortune cookie starts his adventures.

ANGUS, THONGS AND FULL-FRONTAL SNOGGING: Confessions of Georgia Nicolson. By Louise Rennison. HarperCollins. $15.95. (Ages 12 and up) Suppose you combined two modern British diarists, Adrian Mole and Bridget Jones, into a single 14-year-old, added a glossary for American teenagers and had the diary last from just before the beginning of the school year to the end, la Harry Potter. Here's what you'd get. A little raunchy and quite funny.

GOTTA GO! GOTTA GO! By Sam Swope. Illustrated by Sue Riddle. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12. (Ages 3 to 7) The life cycle of the monarch butterfly is told in simple language and illustrations as the story of a creepy-crawly bug who knows that ''I gotta go! I gotta go to Mexico!'' Transformed into a butterfly, she continues to pursue her destiny.

THE BIRTH OF THE MOON. Written and illustrated by Coby Hol. North/South. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 6) Once upon a time, according to this Dutch artist, the animals wondered why the night was dark and asked the sun for light. The sun's gift was wonderful, but the beasts grew greedy. This charming rationale for the phases of the moon is illustrated in cut paper, watercolor and ink.

CHICKEN CHUCK. By Bill Martin Jr. and Bernard Martin. Illustrated by Steven Salerno. Winslow Press. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 7) A morality tale. Chicken Chuck ate a blue seed and grew a blue feather that he thought entitled him to be bossy. But a circus horse has two blue feathers that make the monkey sneeze. Funny.

THE WANDERER. By Sharon Creech. Illustrated by David Diaz. Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins. $15.95. (Ages 8 to 12) An exciting adventure tale, told in diary entries by 13-year-old Sophie and her cousin Cody. They set off from Connecticut for England on a 45-foot sailboat with Sophie's three uncles to visit Sophie's grandfather, who has retired to his native land. Although the boat is equipped with satellite navigation and the brothers are fine sailors, the storm they encounter is nearly fatal.
MRS. HEN'S BIG SURPRISE. Written and illustrated by Christel Desmoinaux. Margaret K. McElderry. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 7) What do you get if you patiently try to hatch a polka-dot egg? Guess.
Julie Yates Walton is a freelance writer.
